6 Minute English
speaker: Sophie

text: from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English, I'm Sophie.
And I'm Neil. So Sophie, the subject of today's show is a traction.
Do you believe in love at first sight?
No, I don't. I think it takes time to get to know somebody
speaker: Sophie

text: well enough to know if you love them.
But I have a friend who says when she saw her husband for the first time.
Uh, that was before they got married.
That's right – when they met for the first time, that was it
speaker: Sophie

text: A bolt out of the blue.
And they got married three months later.
A bolt out of the blue means something totally unexpected.
Well, that sounds very romantic.
And leads me onto today's quiz question.
Sophie, what percentage of Americans said they believe in love at first sight?
speaker: Sophie

text: Is it a 26% b 56% or c 86%?
I'm not an old romantic like you, Neil.
speaker: bolt out of the blue

text: So I'm going to go for a 26%.
Well, we'll find out later on in the show if you're right to be skeptical or not, Sophie.
And skeptical for those of you who don't know,
means to have doubts about something.
speaker: sceptical

text: I think you can be physically attracted to somebody straight away.
I just don't think you can fall in love with somebody so easily.
Love is about other things, compatibility, personality, and a good sense of humour.
Yes, humour is important, but apparently, Sophie, for men
speaker: ratio

text: it's all about the waste hip ratio.
According to research, the ideal waste hip ratio for women is 0.7,
where ratio means the relationship between two sizes.
And you get this figure by dividing the waste measurement by the hip measurement.
I see.
And why do men find 0.7 so irresistible?
Well, let's listen to Dr Anna Machin, an Evolutionary Anthropologist from the University of Oxford,
speaker: Neil

text: explaining what a man is looking for.
He's going to look of signs for fertility and what we call for
quantity and good health.
And the major indicator of that in women is the waste hip ratio.
And the waste hip ratio, the absolute ideal, what men find most attractive,
regardless of culture, this has been tested in many different cultures around the world,
And that's really your classic hourglass figure.
And the reason why that universally is attractive is because it's tied to the health of that
individual. There's a very strong relationship between someone circulating estrogen and
testosterone. Obviously, we want the estrogen to be high, the testosterone to be low for women
to be fertile. And also her general health. So 0.7 is linked to lower risk of heart disease,
lower risk of diabetes and certain sorts of cancers.
So a waste hip ratio of 0.7 correlates or has a strong relationship with good general health
and fertility in women. And the men find this attractive because it identifies fertile women,
women who will be able to conceive or get pregnant and have babies successfully.
speaker: correlates

text: Dr Machin also mentions that 0.7 is the classic hourglass figure – which means curvy
speaker: hourglass figure

text: Do you like curves, Neil? I'm your own business, Sophie.
But all this waste hip theory of attraction isn't very romantic, is it?
You're right, it isn't. And whilst we do judge people by the way they look,
speaker: Neil

text: we also use our senses smell to sniff out our ideal mate or sexual partner.
Apparently, we can detect whether people are genetically different to us,
by the way they smell. And parents who have different immune systems create healthier babies.
So it's back to having babies again – all biology and chemistry
speaker: Neil

text: And not about feelings at all.
Well, let's leave chemistry behind for a moment and listen to Professor David Perrett
at the School of Psychology and Neuroscience at St Andrew's University in Scotland.
He talks about other factors that play a role in attraction.
Classic surgery really doesn't count for much in the end.
You could be with somebody who's aesthetically very beautiful, but if they don't
speaker: David Perrett, Professor at the School of Psychology and Neuroscience at St Andrews University in Scotland

text: smile and react, then that counts for much less.
So we can change our faces by interacting with others and doing so in a pleasant manner.
And that will aid our attractiveness and make others interested in us.
What does aesthetically mean, Sophie?
It means judging something by the way it looks.
speaker: Sophie

text: And whilst we all enjoy a pretty face, most of us are looking for more than that.
We are looking for people who appear friendly and approachable and who we share interests with.
Exactly. And personally, I think kind eyes are very important with a bit of a twinkle.
What about you, Sophie?
I like a good sense of humour.
Very good. Now remember I asked you, Sophie, what percentage of Americans said they believe in love at first sight?
Is it a 26% b 56% or c 86%?
I said 26%.
speaker: Sophie

text: Sorry, that's the wrong answer.
Sophie, 56% of Americans believe in love at first sight.
And the percentage is even higher for married people and those in relationships,
according to a poll conducted by the website cbs.com in 2013.
Well, Americans are a romantic bunch.
speaker: Sophie

text: Me too. And I'm British.
Now, here are the words we heard today.
bolt out of the blue
speaker: Neil

text: Skeptical.
ratio
speaker: Neil

text: Correlates.
Thirtile.
conceive
speaker: Neil

text: Our glass figure.
mate
speaker: Neil

text: Stethically.
Well, that's the end of this edition of 6 Minute English.
